  • City: JACKSONVILLE

item.title: Report X-2025010089
item.description:
Report X-2025010089

Identified by scraper @ 2025-01-08T18:17:50+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-12-24
  • City: TAMPA
  • State: FL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On December 23rd a package was discovered during offloading that had leaked. The package contained UN1170, ethyl alcohol, 3, II, and was marked and labeled appropriately. The inner receptacle does not appear to have been properly prepared for transport, leading to it to break and allowing the liquid to escape. The package was placed into a steel salvage drum and the shipper contacted to pick up.

item.title: Report E-2025010045
item.description:
Report E-2025010045

Identified by scraper @ 2025-01-07T18:25:48+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-12-05
  • City: HIALEAH
  • State: FL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At 2128 ET, Juan Franco with XPO notified ERTS of a cargo release at NMF. It was reported that approximately 20 gallons of BT0222-55 Cetamine V211 released from a 55-gallon DF due to a forklift puncture. The release impacted trailer #5634362 at dock door 76 and has been moved to the yard due to the overwhelming odor. ERTS will proceed to dispatch a contractor to the site to complete cleanup activities. An ETA will be provided once it is known. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 50-gallons of UN2927 BT0222-55 Cetamine V211 released to a 15x8 area of the trailer floor and 100x30 and 10x10 area of the concrete due to forklift puncture. The contractors cleaned the release with absorbents, recollected, and containerized the release into drums, (1) 85-gallon metal drum containing overpacked damaged poly drum, spent absorbents and straps and (1) 65-gallon metal drum containing impacted absorbents, trash bags, and PPE. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.
